revisions.rev:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2008}} {{trainstopics}} This is a '''list of rail accidents from 1950 to 1959'''.
{{Lists of rail accidents}}
__notoc__ <!--begin compact toc--> {| |- ! style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="11"| Notable historic [[train]] accidents, 1950â1959 |- ! style="background:#ddd; text-align:right;"| [[#1950s|1950s]]: | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1950|1950]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1951|1951]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1952|1952]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1953|1953]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1954|1954]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1955|1955]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1956|1956]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1957|1957]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1958|1958]] | style="background:#ddd;"| [[#1959|1959]] |- | style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="11"| [[#See also|See also]] â [[#References|References]] â [[#Sources|Sources]] â [[#External links|External links]] |- | style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="11"| '''Main article links are in bold''' |} <!--end compact toc-->
== 1950s == === 1950 === * February 17, 1950 – [[Rockville Centre, New York]], United States: Two passenger trains collide head-on at [[Rockville Centre (LIRR station)|Rockville Centre train station]]. The engineer of train number 192 ignored an ''Approach'' and the following ''Stop'' signals and collided with train number 175 on temporary [[gauntlet track|gantleted]] (overlapping) track which had been installed to facilitate a grade separation project. Both engineers survived but 31 people were killed, and more than 100 people injured.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=355â356}} * September 11, 1950 – [[Coshocton, Ohio]], United States: The [[Pennsylvania Railroad]]'s train number 31, the westbound ''[[Spirit of St. Louis (train)|Spirit of St. Louis]]'' ignores the warning ''Approach'' signal [maximum speed {{convert|30|mph|0|abbr=on}}, next signal at red] and, traveling at {{convert|48|mph|0|abbr=on}} in dense fog, rear-ends a stopped troop train carrying the 109th Infantry Regiment from [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]], killing 33. The engineer of the ''Spirit of St. Louis'' is to blame.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=251â252}} * November 15, 1950 – '''[[HjuksebÃ¸ train disaster]]''', Norway: seven freight cars ran away from the train to which they should have been attached and collided with a passenger train, killing 14 people. * November 21, 1950 – '''[[Canoe River train crash]]''', British Columbia, Canada: A westbound [[Canadian National Railway]] train carrying Korea-bound [[troop]]s is given incorrectly copied orders and collides with eastbound passenger train number 2, killing 21 people â the enginemen of both trains and 17 soldiers.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=149â150}} * November 22, 1950 – '''[[Kew Gardens train crash]]''', [[New York City]], United States: A collision between two [[Long Island Rail Road]] commuter trains near [[Kew Gardens (LIRR station)|Kew Gardens Station]] killed 79 people and injured 352, making it the worst passenger railroad accident of both LIRR and New York history.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.oldkewgardens.com/ss-lirr-0650.html| title=The 1950 LIRR crash at Kew Gardens/Richmond Hill| date=| accessdate=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.trainsarefun.com/lirr/lirrwrecks/lirrwrecks.htm Long Island Rail Road Wrecks]</ref>{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=357â358}}
===1951=== * February 6, 1951 – '''[[Woodbridge train wreck]]''', [[New Jersey]], United States: ''[[The Broker (passenger train)|The Broker]]'', a [[Pennsylvania Railroad]] passenger train derails, killing 85 people and injuring more than 500.{{sfn|Haine|1993|p=127}}{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=359â361}} * March 16, 1951 – '''[[Doncaster rail crash]]''', derailment at crossover killed 14. [[File:Sakuragicho Train Fire 1951.jpg|thumb|The burning train, SakuragichÅ, Japan, 24 April 1951]] * April 24, 1951 – '''[[SakuragichÅ train fire]]''', A commuter train's pantograph catches fire on the approach to [[SakuragichÅ Station]], [[Yokohama]], Japan, killing at least 106 people and injuring 93.{{sfn|Haine|1993|p=172}}{{sfn|Shaw|1978|p=412}} * June 7, 1951 – '''[[Nova IguaÃ§u level crossing disaster]]''', A commuter train collides with a truck carrying gasoline at a level crossing at [[Nova Iguacu]], northwestern Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, killing at least 54 people.<ref>Haine, 1993, p. 141.</ref> * July 22, 1951 – [[TatranskÃ¡ Lomnica, Slovakia|TatranskÃ¡ Lomnica]], [[Czechoslovakia]] (now [[Slovakia]]): In the Slovakian Tatra Mountains (VysokÃ© Tatry), two ÄSD passengers cars collide. 19 people are killed. A similar crash had occurred in 1895 at the same place.<ref>{{sk icon}} {{cite web|url=http://rail.sk/arp/slovakia/history/h185-4.htm|title=Å½elezniÄnÃ¡ traÅ¥ TatranskÃ¡ Lomnica - StudenÃ½ Potok}}</ref> * August 18, 1951 – [[SzÃ©kesfehÃ©rvÃ¡r]], Hungary: A fast train ran into the end of a local commuter train. 6 people died in the accident (also a conductor), and 3 more after transfer to hospital. 28 passengers injured.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * August 18, 1951 – [[Debrecen]], Hungary: A passenger train heading for TiszalÃ¶k collided with a shunting DMU. 11 passengers died because of the wooden-frame coaches.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * September 21, 1951 – '''[[Weedon rail crash (1951)|Weedon rail crash]]''': Defective maintenance on locomotive bogie causing derailment which killed 15. * November 12, 1951 â A rear-end collision on the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] kills 17 people.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|p=463}} * November 25, 1951 â A head-on collision on the [[Southern Railway (United States)|Southern Railway]] kills 17 people.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|p=463}} * December 17, 1951 – '''[[Piquet Carneiro train crash]]''': A derailment due to excess speed at [[Piquet Carneiro]] in Brazil kills 53.
===1952=== * March 4, 1952 â '''[[Anchieta rail disaster]]''' near [[Rio de Janeiro]] kills 119 people when a high-speed electric freight train collides with a derailed passenger train. * May 7, 1952 – A fully laden passenger train collides in dense fog with a stationary train at [[Berala railway station]], Australia. 10 people are killed and 137 injured.<ref>[http://newspapers.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/2859233 Berala Inquest]. ''[[The Canberra Times]]''. July 10, 1952.</ref><ref>[http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=yicRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GcQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3941,810236&dq= Sydney rail disaster cause not yet solved]. ''[[The Age]]''. May 8, 1952.</ref> * August 16, 1952 â Former [[Soviet Army]] carrying passenger train derailed at [[Rzepin]], [[Slubice]], Poland, 23 officers and 136 soldiers are killed.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * August 26, 1952 â [[Suchdol nad Odrou]], [[Czechoslovakia]]: A fast train derails, killing 12 people and injuring 108.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * October 8, 1952 – '''[[Harrow and Wealdstone rail crash]]''': Three trains are involved in a crash that kills 112 people and injures 340. A [[rear-end collision]] due to a driver [[signal passed at danger|passing a signal at danger]] in fog is immediately followed by another express running into the wreckage.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/october/8/newsid_3075000/3075197.stm Many die as three trains crash at Harrow]. [[BBC News]]. October 8, 1952.</ref> * December 26, 1952 â [[Budapest]], Hungary: A local train from [[Szentendre]] derails because of a faulty switch killing 26 and injuring 57. The switch attendant was executed on the same day.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}}
=== 1953 === * January 15, 1953 – [[Washington, D.C.]], United States: Approaching [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]], the brakes partially fail on the [[Pennsylvania Railroad]] ''[[Federal Express (passenger train)|Federal Express]]'' overnight train from [[Boston]]. Unable to stop, the 16 car train careened through the [[interlocking]], barreled into sixteen track, a [[stub (railway)|stub]] track, plowed through the bumper and smashed its way into the station, destroying the main [[newsstand]] and the [[stationmaster]]'s office. The massive [[PRR GG1|GG1]] [[electric locomotive]] pulling the train collapsed the [[concourse]] floor and fell into the [[basement]]. Amazingly, nobody was killed by the accident. President-elect [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s inauguration was scheduled the next week, leaving insufficient time to extricate the locomotive, so the basement was planked over for the celebration week. After the inaugural festivities had concluded, the locomotive was cut into three sections, hauled to the Pennsylvania Railroad's [[Altoona Works|Altoona shops]], where it was rebuilt and returned to revenue service for another three decades. GG1 [[PRR 4876|No. 4876]] is in the collection of the [[B&O Railroad Museum]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dcnrhs.org/union_station/union_wreck.htm|title=The Famous Union Station Wreck|publisher=National Railway Historical Society|accessdate=2007-04-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070407193219/http://www.dcnrhs.org/union_station/union_wreck.htm |archivedate = April 7, 2007}}</ref>{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=221â224}} * March 27, 1953 – [[Conneaut, Ohio]], United States: Three [[New York Central]] trains tangle near Conneaut on the four-track mainline on the night of March 27. Twenty-one passengers die. The cause is found to be an improperly secured gondola loadâa section of {{convert|13|in|mm|adj=on|sigfig=2}} pipe fell from a freight car onto the adjacent track and was struck by a passenger train.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=212â213}} * April 8, 1953 â '''[[Stratford tube crash]]''': 12 people were killed as a result of a rear-end collision in a tunnel. * June 24, 1953 â '''[[1953 Col des Nuages derailment]]''': "About 100 or more" people are killed when a passenger train plunges 50 feet through a sabotaged viaduct in [[French Indochina]] (now Vietnam). Two locomotives and 18 cars crashed down in a ravine at a mountain pass on the route between the ancient Vietnamese capital of Huáº¿ and the port of Tourane ([[Da Nang]]). The pass had frequently been the scene of attacks by the Communist-led [[Viet Minh]] rebels. Officials said that a strong charge exploded just as the train arrived at the viaduct, tumbling a 25-foot span into the ravine.<ref>Fort Walton Beach, Florida, "Indochina Rail Crash Kills 100". Playground News, 25 June 1953, Volume 8, Number 22, p. 8.</ref> * 15 August 1953 – '''[[Irk Valley Junction rail crash]]''', ten die when the front carriages of an electric train plunge off a viaduct following a collision. * December 19, 1953 – '''[[Sydenham Rail Disaster]]''', Australia: a passenger train of the [[New South Wales Railways]] runs into the rear of another train. Five people are killed and 748 injured. * December 24, 1953 – '''[[Å akvice train disaster]]''', [[Czechoslovakia]] (now Czech Republic): Express train whose crew fell asleep after several [[Driving under the influence|bottles of wine]] hits commuter train at a station, killing 106 people. * December 24, 1953 – '''[[Tangiwai disaster]]''', New Zealand: an overnight [[Wellington]] to [[Auckland]] express train fell into the [[Whangaehu River]], after the rail bridge was destroyed by a [[lahar]] from [[Mount Ruapehu]]'s crater lake just minutes earlier. 151 people were killed.
===1955=== * January 23, 1955 â '''[[Sutton Coldfield train disaster]]''', England: a passenger train rounds a sharp curve too fast and derails at [[Sutton Coldfield]] station; 17 people die as a result. * April 3, 1955 â [[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]], Mexico: a train falls into a canyon. 13 killed.{{sfn|Haine|1993|p=175}} * July 17, 1955 - '''[[San Bernardo train crash]]''', [[San Bernardo, Chile]], Collision in fog, 38 people killed, 58 injured. * August 22, 1955 â Spring City Train Disaster, [[Spring City, Tennessee]], United States: [[School bus]] disregards [[crossing signal]] and is struck by freight train. 11 people dead, 39 hurt; all the dead are school children.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * September 23, 1955 â [[Torreón]], Mexico: A mixed passenger/freight train collides with one of two trucks carrying explosives, whose drivers were racing each other. Both trucks explode. At least 65 people killed, 100 injured.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dynamite-Laden Trucks, Train Collide in Mexico Bringing 65 Fatalities |location=Hendersonville, North Carolina |newspaper=Times-News |page=1 |date=1955-09-24 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DEIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hyMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4583,4610241 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bulletin |location=Toronto |newspaper=Globe and Mail |date=1955-09-24 |page=1}}</ref> * November 20, 1955 â '''[[Milton rail crash]]''': a passenger train takes a [[Railroad switch|crossover]] too fast and derails at Milton, near [[Didcot]], England. 11 people killed, 157 injured. * December 2, 1955 â '''[[Barnes rail crash]]''', [[Barnes, London|Barnes]], [[South London]], England: collision due to signal error and consequent fire. 13 people killed, 35 injured.
===1956===
* January 22, 1956 â '''[[Redondo Junction train wreck]]''', [[Los Angeles, California]], United States: Bound for [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], two coupled [[Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway|Santa Fe]] Rail Diesel Cars ([[Budd Rail Diesel Car|RDCs]]), making up train No. 82, derail and topple over at 69 mph in an evening high-speed accident, killing 30 persons on board and seriously injuring 117. The accident marked the end of the RDC units' service on the Santa Fe company's "Surf Line."{{sfn|Shaw|1978|p=302}} * February 14, 1956 - '''[[1956 Santiago rail crash|Santiago rail crash]]''': 23 people were killed and 198 injured when two trains collided in fog near [[Santiago, Chile]]. * February 28, 1956 â Swampscott, Massachusetts: A [[Boston and Maine Railroad]] [[Budd Rail Diesel Car|RDC]] train runs into the back of another stationary passenger train which had stopped due to signals being obscured by fallen snow. Thirteen people are killed.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=254â254}} * September 5, 1956 â near Robinson, New Mexico, United States: Two Santa Fe express passenger trains collide when a railroad worker prematurely throws a switch directly in front of one of the trains. 20 railroad employees, mostly dining car personnel, are killed.{{sfn|Shaw|1978|pp=114â115}} * October 13, 1956 - [[Longmoor Military Railway]], [[Hampshire]], United Kingdom. A passenger train hauled by [[LMS Stanier Class 8F|Class 8F]] [[2-8-0]] WD512 is involved in a head-on collision with an permanent way train hauled by [[0-6-0]] [[LMS diesel shunters|diesel shunter]] WD877 ''Bari'' between Weaversdown Halt and Liss Forest Road stations. Six soldier are killed and eight are injured.<ref name=HR156>{{cite journal |title=Six die in Longmoor's blackest day - but was there a military cover-up? |first=David |last=Willcock |journal= Heritage Railway |issue=No. 156, 27 October - 23 November 2011 |pages=pp.62-66 |publisher=Mortons Media Ltd |location=Horncastle |issn=1466-3350}}</ref> * October 15, 1956 â Mikumo (present day [[Matsusaka]]), [[Mie Prefecture|Mie]], Japan: A [[Nagoya]]–[[Toba, Mie|Toba]] express passenger train collides [[head-on]] with another express train, and then a passenger train derailed on a safety catch point, crushing four passenger cars in [[Rokken Station (Mie)|Rokken Station]], killing 44 people and injuring 94. {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} * October 18, 1956 â Pineola, Florida, United States: Head-on collision between two [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad]] freight trains. Five crewmen are killed.<ref>[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:WST_Great_Train_Wreck_of_1956(Pineola,_Florida).jpg Site of Great Train Wreck of 1956 on Withlacoochee State Trail (Commons)]</ref> * November 23, 1956 â A Madras-Tuticorin Express derailed at Maradaiyar River bridge at Ariyalur, Tamil-Nadu, India, killing at least 154 people.<ref>Kumar, Virendra. ''Committees And Commissions In India Volume 12 : 1974''. Concept Publishing Company, 1993, p. 285.</ref>
=== 1957 ===
* March 15, 1957 – near [[Kuurila]], Finland: Southbound night express train from Tornio to Helsinki collides head-on with the HelsinkiâPori express train. 26 people killed and 60 injured. * April 27, 1957 – [[Bylnice]], [[Czechoslovakia]] (now Czech Republic):wagon runs away during [[shunt (railway operations)|shunting]] from Brumov station and collides with a passenger train carrying 20 people, killing 10 and injuring 4. * September 1, 1957 – [[Manchester, Jamaica]], [[British West Indies]]: Chartered train returning to Kingston from Montego Bay derails, killing 197 people and injuring more than 700.<ref>[[Railways of Jamaica#Accidents]]</ref> * September 29, 1957 – [[Sahiwal|Montgomery]], Pakistan: An express train crashes into an oil train. 250 people killed. * October 20, 1957 – Two passenger trains, one being the ''[[Simplon Orient Express]]'' collide [[head-on]] at [[Sirkeci]], outskirt of [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], killing at least 95 people and injuring another 150. * December 4, 1957 – '''[[Lewisham rail crash]]''', England: A steam train passes a red signal in the fog and ploughs into the back of an electric train. The crash also destroys a support column of a railway bridge, causing parts of the bridge to collapse onto the wreck. 90 people are killed. * December 23, 1957 – Diesel multiple unit runs into the back of another train in dense fog on the [[Harcourt Street railway line]] at [[Dundrum, Dublin]], killing the driver.
===1958=== * January 1, 1958 – an Ambala-Delhi local train collided with standing [[Delhi]]–[[Pathankot]] express at [[Mohri]] station, [[Ambala]], [[Haryana]], India, killing at least 32 people, another 85 are injured. * January 30, 1958 – '''[[Dagenham East rail crash]]''', [[Dagenham]], United Kingdom: A commuter train passes a danger signal and rear-ends the stopped train in front of it, killing 10 people and injuring 89. * May 8, 1958 – '''[[1958 Rio de Janeiro train crash]]''', [[Brazil]]: a commuter express train rams and crashes into another commuter train. Wreckage of cars is piled along embankments under a highway overpass near Mangueira station, in the outskirts of [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. The accident kills 140 people and injures another 300. * September 14, 1958 – [[Drachenfels Railway]], [[KÃ¶nigswinter]], Germany: A [[rack railway]] train derails, killing 17 people. * September 15, 1958 – '''[[Newark Bay, New Jersey rail crash]]''', United States: A [[Central Railroad of New Jersey]] morning commuter train blows through stop signals, derails, then slides off of the open liftspan. Both diesels and first two coaches plunge into Newark Bay and sink immediately, 48 people drown. A third coach hangs precariously out the drawbridge for two hours, snagged by its rear truck before it, too, topples into the water. All passengers on the third coach escape. As the whole operating crew was killed, no absolute determination for the accident was reached, but a medical emergency in the cab was theorized.
===1959=== * March 18, 1959 – [[Beavercreek, Ohio]] A car with 8 Girl Scouts and 2 troop leaders of the Beavercreek Girl Scouts is struck by a freight train at the Factory Road crossing at Beavercreek, Ohio, killing all occupants. In memory of the victims of this tragedy the Angels Pass Memorial was placed at the Beavercreek Community Park.<ref>"[http://www.daytondailynews.com/n/content/oh/story/news/local/2009/03/18/ddn031809angelspass.html Crash killed 10 Scouts, leaders 50 years ago], ''Dayton Daily News''.</ref> * May 28, 1959 – A [[Gambir, Jakarta]] to [[Parahyangan, Bandung]] express derails and plunges into a ravine on the outskirts of Tjipeundeuj, [[West Java]], [[Indonesia]], killing 92 people and injuring 40. * June 5, 1959 – [[SÃ£o Paulo]], Brazil: Two commuter trains collide head-on in Engenheiro Goulart station, killing 56 people and injuring 100. {{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} * June 28, 1959 – '''[[Meldrim, Georgia trestle disaster]]''', United States: Tank cars carrying [[butane]] derail atop a wooden trestle owned by the [[Seaboard Air Line Railroad]]. The resulting explosion and fire kills 23.<ref>"[http://www.meldrim.com/page6.html I.C.C. Official Investigation, Meldrim Trestle Disaster, June 28, 1959]". Retrieved March 27, 2007.</ref> * October 2, 1959 – Dabrowa Bydgoska (near [[Bydgoszcz]]): A passenger train collides with a postal bus, killing 23 people.
